source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium and zirconium alloys provide the best combination of metallurgical and mechanical properties for light and heavy water nuclear reactor fuel cladding and for the primary steam generation equipment.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium has good corrosion resistance to high temperature, high pressure water and steam, good mechanical strength and ductility, and a low thermal neutron cross section.
property_name: corrosion resistance, mechanical strength, ductility, thermal neutron cross section

conditions.medium: high temperature, high pressure water and steam

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: Zirconium is superior to stainless steel and nickel for these applications because of the following qualities: (a) corrosion resistance, (b) strength under long-term neutron bombardment, (c) neutron economy, (d) compatibility with zirconium fuel cladding, eliminating water chemistry problems, and (e) reactivity build up a major factor in reactor refueling and maintenance costs.
property_name: corrosion resistance, strength, neutron economy, compatibility, reactivity build up

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: TRR reactor vessel (calandria) is constructed entirely of zirconium alloy (ASTM Grade RA-1)

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The calandria is a 9000 lb cylindrical vessel, having its axis vertical. The vessel is 106-in. diameter (inside) and approximately 129-in. high

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk1
evidence_span: The calandria is a weldment of reactor grade zirconium alloy purchased in compliance with American Society for Testing and Materials (ASTM) Specification for Zirconium and Zirconium Alloy Ingots for Nuclear Application (B 350-67), Specification for Hot-Rolled and Cold-Finished Zirconium and Zirconium Alloy Bars, Rod, and Wire for Nuclear Application (B 351-67), Specification for Zirconium and Zirconium Alloy Sheet, Strip, and Plate for Nuclear Applications (B 352-67), and Specification for Zirconium and Zirconium Alloy Forgings and Extrusions for Nuclear Application (B 356-67).

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: Zirconium has for several years been used in such non-nuclear applications as chemical processing plants. The complete range of processing equipment has been manufactured from zirconium such as condenser towers, reactor vessels, pumps, valves, and piping. This equipment has been used in the processing of corrosive media at temperatures ranging up to 700°F (371°C) which is the useful range of zirconium in atmosphere.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: The test specimens were made from base metal as well as welded coupons in order to simulate the fabricated condition of the metal.

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: The creep strength and creep rupture tests were performed for test duration periods of 10,000 h or longer with 100,000 h creep tests still in progress.

evidence_span: The creep strength and creep rupture tests were performed for test duration periods of 10,000 h or longer with 100,000 h creep tests still in progress.

evidence_span: Based on this criterion, it is shown on Fig. 7 that the maximum allowable design stress for zirconium ASTM Grade 702 (unalloyed zirconium) is onefourth ultimate tensile strength at temperatures up to 700°F

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: Based on this criterion, Fig. 8 shows that maximum strength values for unalloyed zirconium (ASTM Grades 704 and R-1) as well as Zircaloy (ASTM Grades 705 and RA-1 or RA-2) is one-third ultimate tensile strength at temperatures up to 800°F (427°C).

source_id: STP551-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_2nd Volume_004_chunk2
evidence_span: Although not an ASTM specified material, the alloy Zr-2.5Cb has been developed for nuclear uses where superior strength and creep resistance are required.
